content: naughty deer sweater yoke charts a classic nordic-style yoke a line of leaping deer and one slightly less subtle moment of deer biology these charts capture the motif as knit in the original sweater shared for personal use inspiration and a bit of humor in stranded knitting this isn t a full-blown sweater pattern but i tried to write down a bit of a recipe for what i did for my own sweater i also included the measurements of my own sweater so you have an idea of the dimensions i will try to get a grip on grading and may try to make a proper pattern out of this but to get this out for people to knit while it s still sweater weather this is the best i can do in a short amount of time ps i used stitch fiddle to generate the digital versions of the charts i wish you all lots of fun with these charts happy knitting cheers ariane notes on fit & construction this sweater was designed and knit by a very tall person as a result the yoke depth may be too deep for average-height knitters you may wish to adjust the depth by either omitting part of the chart or by working the yoke with smaller needle sizes see recommendations below the sweater is worked top down in the round beginning at the collar for this sample 18 chart repeats were used 17 × jumping deer 1 × humping deer materials used yarn main color body merino yarn 50 g / 250 m ≈ 273 yds knitting for olive held together with soft silk mohair 25 g / 225 m ≈ 246 yds knitting for olive contrast color colorwork alpaca peru 200 50 g / 200 m ≈ 219 yds lana grossa held together with soft silk mohair 25 g / 225 m ≈ 246 yds knitting for olive yardage used sample 250 g merino + 125 g soft silk mohair main color slightly more than 50 g alpaca peru 200 + 25 g soft silk mohair contrast color if you prefer a longer body length it is recommended to use at least 150 g of soft silk mohair in the main color needles & tools circular needle 3 mm us 2½ ribbing circular needle 3 5 mm us 4 body and colorwork cable length 80 cm / 32 inches 18 stitch markers 2 spare cables or waste yarn for holding sleeve stitches abbreviations bor beginning of round st s stitch es k knit p purl k2tog knit two stitches together ssk slip slip knit m1 make one stitch mm stitch marker repeat repeat gauge stockinette stitch 3 5 mm us 4 needles 10 × 10 cm / 4 × 4 inches 22 stitches × 33 row gauge and measurements refer to the sweater
